In the example beginning at 27:10, a key piece of information is missing from the statement of the problem: the reaction is happening in a fixed volume.  If the reaction happened at a fixed pressure (for example, in a flexible container under atmospheric pressure), you would have to calculate the pressure changes differently as reactant is consumed, and you would get a somewhat different answer.  Qualitatively, you can see that if all the pressures are increased proportionately, it has more effect on the numerator of K because the reactant partial pressure is squared.  So more of the reactant gets consumed, in accordance with Le Chatelier's principle.
